What is the Overlay Specification?

Outline (What is the Overlay Specification?)

  1. What is the Overlay Specification? [2]
  2. Overlay Specification Overview [3]
  3. Overlays in API Pipelines [3]
What is the Overlay Specification? Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(3) What is the OpenAPI Overlay Specification?

  • The OpenAPI Overlay Specification defines a way to modify an existing OpenAPI document without changing the original file.
  • Overlays are separate YAML / JSON documents containing structured actions (add, update, remove) targeting parts of an OpenAPI document.
  • Targets are identified using JSONPath expressions, enabling precise and repeatable transformations.
  • The Overlay Specification is an official OAI standard (v1.0.0) designed to support cleaner API workflows and automation.
  • Overlays allow changes to be applied incrementally, layered, and versioned independently of the base OpenAPI Document.


What is the Overlay Specification? Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(4) Why Use Overlays?

  • Separation of concerns: Keep the canonical API definition clean, while applying environment-, audience-, or workflow-specific changes via overlays.
  • Consistency & automation: Apply repeatable updates across OpenAPI docs (e.g., documentation, metadata, security, examples) without manual editing.
  • Multi-audience support: Generate public, private, partner, or internal API descriptions from one source using different overlays.
  • Avoids oversharing: Remove internal endpoints or sensitive fields for public-facing specs without duplicating files.
  • Integration in pipelines: Overlays can be applied during CI/CD to prepare API definitions for documentation, SDKs, testing, or gateways.
  • Localization: Translating documentation into another language.

OpenAPI + Overlays = (better) OpenAPI!



Overlay Specification Overview

Outline (Overlay Specification Overview)

  1. What is the Overlay Specification? [2]
  2. Overlay Specification Overview [3]
  3. Overlays in API Pipelines [3]
Overlay Specification Overview Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(6) Overlay Specification Overview

  • An Overlay document has three top-level fields: overlay (version), info, and actions.
  • Actions are processed in order, allowing sequential and predictable transformations to the base OpenAPI spec.
  • Each Action Object contains a target (a JSONPath expression) and an operation such as update, add, remove, or merge.
  • Targets can point to any part of the OpenAPI document: paths, operations, parameters, descriptions, vendor extensions, security, metadata, etc.
  • Overlays are fully valid YAML/JSON documents and can be version-controlled and reused across pipelines.


Overlay Specification Overview Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(7) Basic Overlay Example – Updating Descriptions

  • Overlays can enrich generated or minimal OpenAPI specs with documentation.
  • Example: enhance the API's description field without touching the source OpenAPI Document.
  • Example Overlay:
              overlay: 1.0.0
              info:
                title: Improve API Descriptions
                version: 0.1.0
              actions:
                - target: "$.info.description"
                  update:
                    description: "Public API for MyService – includes endpoints for books and orders."
  • This updates info.description in the output OpenAPI Document when the overlay is applied.


Overlay Specification Overview Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(8) Advanced Overlay Example – Remove Internal Endpoints

  • Overlays can remove elements based on metadata (e.g., internal endpoints marked with x-internal: true).
  • Useful for creating a public version of an API from an internal canonical OpenAPI Document.
  • Example Overlay:
              overlay: 1.0.0
              info:
                title: Public API Variant
                version: 1.0.0
              actions:
                - target: "$.paths.*[?(@.x-internal == true)]"
                  remove: true
  • This removes all paths or operations marked as internal from the final OpenAPI Document.
  • Can be combined with overlays adding public-facing docs, examples, or vendor extensions.


Overlays in API Pipelines

Outline (Overlays in API Pipelines)

  1. What is the Overlay Specification? [2]
  2. Overlay Specification Overview [3]
  3. Overlays in API Pipelines [3]
Overlays in API Pipelines Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(10) Where Overlays Fit in the API Lifecycle

  • Begin with a canonical OpenAPI Description (often code-generated or design-first).
  • Apply overlays to inject descriptions, examples, tags, rate limits, or other metadata without altering the base OpenAPI Document.
  • Use multiple overlays to tailor the API for different audiences: public, partner, internal, or operational.
  • Generate derived specs during CI/CD for documentation portals, SDK generation, gateways, mocks, or testing tools.
  • Overlays help maintain a single source of truth while enabling flexible downstream representations.


Overlays in API Pipelines Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(11) Automation & CI/CD Integration

  • Overlays can be applied as automated steps during the build or release process.
  • Ensures documentation, SDKs, and other artifacts are always generated from a validated and enriched spec.
  • Important for large teams where manual edits would be error-prone or inconsistent.
  • Overlay application is deterministic: the same overlay + same base OpenAPI Document produces the same result every time.
  • Ideal for pipelines that produce “public”, “internal”, “sandbox”, or “gateway-ready” specs from one base definition.


Overlays in API Pipelines Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays

(12) When to Use Overlays (and When Not To)

  • Use overlays when:
    • You maintain a single authoritative OpenAPI Description but need multiple consumer-specific derivatives.
    • You want to enrich autogenerated OpenAPI Docs with human-friendly descriptions and examples.
    • You want to strip internal endpoints or sensitive details before publishing publicly.
    • You want to version documentation changes separately from functional API changes.
  • Avoid overlays when:
    • The change reflects reality of the core API itself (e.g., adding a real endpoint or schema change).
    • Your tooling ecosystem does not yet support overlay application.
    • You have highly dynamic schemas where direct design-first maintenance is preferred.


Frank Kilcommins: API Description Pipelines with Overlays
